awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type I: Johns Hopkins University I-Corps Site for Viable Startup Creation
awd_abstract_narration:
The intellectual merit of this project at Johns Hopkins University (JHU) is that the Johns Hopkins Technology Ventures (JHTV) and its accelerator team, FastForward, will support the commercialization of research and technologies to create an innovation ecosystem at the University, and more broadly, in the Baltimore region. This I-Corps Site award enables JHU to leverage research outcomes by providing teams with an essential stipend for customer discovery and prototyping and the ability to validate and test their hypotheses and confirm through customer discovery whether there is value in their technology in the marketplace. By actually getting out of the lab, researchers gain insights into the mindset of decision makers and the payers who may become their customers. This grant will enable the JHU Site to provide a better learning experience for its participants by providing additional, non-dilutive funds.

For example, in the fall of 2015, JHU's Short Course cohort focused on life sciences and brought together teams from universities across the city. The focused approach allowed instructors to delve into the unique challenges faced by researchers commercializing technology in the life sciences space including the development of strategic partnerships and the need for greater evidence based research at a time when the life science industry is investing less in research and development and easing away from the risks of basic and translational research.

The I-Corps Site at JHU fills the fundamental educational disconnect between invention and market that is not found inside a lab or classroom but only through customer interviews. The goal of the JHU I-Corps Site will be to advance the knowledge and understanding of the commercial potential of life and basic science research while providing access to the life science expertise of Johns Hopkins to include translation, partnering, and entrepreneurship for the greater National
Innovation Network.

Participants in the JHU Site include teams from other universities especially those with diverse populations such as University of Maryland Baltimore City, Morgan State University, and Coppin State University, fostering collaboration and economic growth in the city and beyond. Over five years, this grant will impact 150 JHU teams and to a minimum 45 non-JHU teams, each comprised of three team members, for a total of at least 585 participants.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The I-Corps Site program at Johns Hopkins University (JHU) allows academic teams to extend their focus beyond the university laboratory and accelerates the economic and societal benefits of research projects that are ready to move toward commercialization. Through I-Corps, participants learn to identify valuable product opportunities that can emerge from academic research, and gain skills in entrepreneurship through training in customer discovery and guidance from established entrepreneurs. The Site awards a modest sum of funding to teams that participate in the program to further customer discovery and prototype development.

I-Corps fills the fundamental educational disconnect between invention and market that is not found inside a lab or classroom but only through customer interviews. As an Affiliate in the Mid-Atlantic Hub, JHU’s goal will be to advance the knowledge and understanding of the commercial potential of life and basic science research while providing access to the life science expertise of JHU to include translation, partnering, and entrepreneurship for the greater National Innovation Network.

Since the inception of the program at Johns Hopkins University, 252 different teams have participated in our I-Corps program. As a result, 131 Site Grant Awards provided up to $545,000 in reimbursement to continue to advance their startups through further customer discovery and prototyping. 

The faculty, student, and entrepreneurial leads that participated in our program either learned or strengthened their knowledge of problem-solution fit, solution-customer fit, and a better understanding of value propositions and initial target customer segments. University inventors who have participated in the program have learned valuable business skills and incorporate these findings to identify future potential commercial applications of their research. 

Furthermore, many of our University staff from the Technology Ventures office audited the I-Corps cohorts to strengthen their own knowledge of the above-mentioned lessons. This will also hopefully ensure these colleagues are advocates for the program and a lead source for future participants. 

Our program has been featured on our company website, newsletter, targeted email marketing campaigns, and social media. We have worked with key influencers at the Universities by using prolific inventors, department chairs, and administrators to spread the word about our program.

We also share our program dates and opportunities more broadly to the 10 Universities participating in the Mid-Atlantic I-Corps Hub, as well as to other local Universities in the Baltimore ecosystem.

The support of the NSF I-Corps Grant at the University has been profound. Before the award, 68 University teams had participated in I-Corps over the course of three years. Since the inception of the Award at Johns Hopkins, 252 teams have now participated.

In addition to the tenets of customer discover and value propositions, the teams have also used the program to develop business plans and workflow maps. These philosophies have been incorporated into various entrepreneurial accelerators and other educational programming provided by the University. 

The teams participating in our I-Corps program have built a community of entrepreneurs and have been able to help identify which team members are committed to moving technologies forward. According to our sources, over 580 people are actively employed by startups that have participated in our I-Corps program.

To date, 17 teams who have participated in I-Corps have formed startups that have rented space in our innovation hubs, including 8 current tenants. 46 past I-Corps teams have incorporated and licensed technologies from Johns Hopkins Technology Transfer. 33 of these startups are still active, and 3 have been acquired. Furthermore, we have 5 teams actively negotiating licenses to technology to form new startup companies. 

Many of these teams are working on commercializing University technologies that can have profound and wide-reaching impacts on society at large. Examples include early cancer screening technology, industrial robotics, mosquito surveillance of disease spread, and prevention of arrest-related deaths. Past participant teams have gone on to raise over $342M collectively to their startup companies. 

 


Last Modified: 09/14/2022
Modified by: Brian Stansky
